Speaker: Mr DOWNER
Title: EOYAL COMMISSION ON
text: Angas) [5.0] - This debate has lasted for some days. It is pleasing to note, from the view-point of the outside world, the general agreement among honourable members on both sides of the House on the basic thesis that the Prime Minister (Mr Menzies) and the Minister for External Affairs (Mr. Casey) put forward.' Most honourable members, quite obviously, support the Prime Minister's historic statement. He gave a realistic and factual appreciation of events in South-East Asia, and I have not heard any honourable member seriously quarrel with his forebodings for the future and his plan to meet it. I listened to the strictures that the honourable member for Kennedy (Mr Riordan) made on the Government's defence policy. Of course, one could pick flaws in any administration's defence policy, but the fact remains that this country is more prepared than it has ever been before in a time of peace. If criticism of Australia's defences must be made, it is singular that it should come from members of the Opposition, because when the Government sought to recruit support for its enlistment campaign for the army not so long ago it was met with sneers and a blank refusal from honourable members opposite. Yet, those honourable members now try to castigate the Government for allegedly leaving this country in a state of unpreparedness. Never before has this House, on so great an issue, been treated to such hypocrisy. If honourable members will bear with Gome for a. few moments, I " shall return to the point at which this debate was commenced and give a brief review of the very parlous situation in which we now find ourselves. The only satisfaction that any of us can derive from the truce in Indo-China is that the frightfulnesa of war has stopped. In terms of grand strategy, it represents for the democracies a military and diplomatic defeat of considerable magnitude. It is, undoubtedly, another nail in the coffin of whito prestige in Asia. After seven year3 of fighting, involving great loss of life and the outpouring of huge subsidies fvom the TJnited States of America, our ally, France, has been driven to seek a negotiated peace. In the result, Indo-China is no longer to be held. It is to be relinquished by instalments-mos t of Viet Nam now; the remainder, one must assume, aftev the elections in 1956. The majority of the Vietnamese population has already passed under Communist control. Partition, on the model of Korea, is explicitly denied. However, it is scarcely conceivable that in the elections that are to be held in 1956, the Communists, with their superior military might, their propaganda and their crusading zeal will not win. Let no man imagine that this settlement is final. Is international communism to renounce its ambition at the seventeenth parallel? To assume that, would be contrary to all previous experience. Viet Minh pressure on neighbouring Laos and Cambodia will continue relentlessly, despite what was said and settled a fortnight ago at Geneva. Already, the Viet Minh are masters of a considerable degree of territory contiguous to Siam and Burma. "Who can doubt that these two countries are not next on the list to be struck down? Coming further south, is it not reasonable to suppose that Malaya will shovtly be affected? We can anticipate once more a. recrudescence of terrorism throughout that peninsula. Who of us can view with equanimity the internal state of our nearest foreign neighbour, Indonesia? The Govevnment of that country is riding uneasily in the saddle, unable to exert its authority throughout its own domains; whilst the Indonesian Pavliament still lacks the sanction of popular elections. The Prime Minister is wise in assumof ing that the Viet Minh victory, confirmed at Geneva, will strengthen the Communist cause throughout Asia. He is also right this proposed pact. in affirming that there is not a moment lose so far as the Anglo-American powers ave concerned. The war, indeed, has ceased, but the torrent of which war was the expression progresses. In common with the great majority of tralians, I welcome the intense intevest shown by the TJnited States of America in a theatre so vital to Australia. is unnecessary to argue now whether Ur. Downer. Mr John Foster Dulles was right in seeking a South-East Asia Treaty Organization before the Geneva conference was held. There were obvious objections to such a move, but, at least in defence of the American Secretary of State, it can be said that he was realistic. Whatever honourable members may feel on this question, it is as clear as summer sunlight that a joint defence organization must be established forthwith having the TJnited Kingdom as its covnevstone, and buttressed by the TJnited States and Australia. Let us all support the Prime Minister in trying to persuade those nations in Asia, which arc as intevested as ourselves in opposing Communist imperialism, to become partners in this grand alliance. Happily, Siam and the Philippines appear willing. Perhaps Burma, with its experience of red insurrection, and because of its natural fear of Communist penetration, will regard its true friends with a less suspicious eye. The Minister for External Affairs has told us of his attempt to interest the Governments of India and Pakistan in this scheme. We are naturally disappointed that they are apparently viewing it coldly. One must respect their motives anc? their reactions, but it is not too much to hope that in the coming months they may revise their estimates and be prepared to join the organization at a subsequent stage. In discussing this matter we should emphasize how wrong it is of any section of Asian opinion to interpret Australian support for Seato as a reactionary attempt to restore so-called colonialism in the East. It is regrettable, for example, to find the Prime Minister Ceylon, Sir John Kotelawala, only last week using the phrase, " a revival oif western imperialism", in connection with It cannot be to emphasized too strongly that colonialism, as such, is a phase of the past. It has gone into history. No European nation is thinking along those lines today. Long before World War II - the Leader of Austhe Opposition, if he were more just, might have emphasized this pointBvitish policy throughout the Empire It aimed at self-government by progressivt, stages. During a great period, British administrators gave those over whom tliey ruled, tutelage, and an increasing share of local administration. Since the end of "World War II . , Great Britain has shown a generosity, an enlightenment, and a recognition of national aspirations, unparalleled in the history of any imperial power. India and Burma were granted their independence. Ceylon has received dominion status. The Gold Coast and Nigeria are on the point of attaining a similar prize. Greatly enhanced authority is now being conferred on the legislatures of Malaya and Singapore. This liberal, understanding spirit is confined to the Mother Country. It , likewise, animates Australia's approach to our northern neighbours. We have shown over the years a strong practical sympathy with their needs. The Colombo plan, be it ever remembered to the credit of this Government, was launched in 1950. Its contribution, it is true, has so far been limited, but it proclaims an important principle capable of great expansion. It shows plainly to the five countries which we are succouring that, far from seeking to dominate them, we wish to elevate their living standards nearer to our own. I believe that the Government will do more in this direction. It is obvious that it should. I also hope that the Australian people, both on grounds of humanity and of national interest, will sanction an increasing diversion of the proceeds of taxation for this purpose over a period which, inevitably, will endure for many years. No discussion of Australia's Asian policy can be adequate without reference to the contentious subject of China. I have been surprised that in this debate practically no honourable member, with the exception of the Minister for the Interior (Mr Kent Hughes), has alluded to this phase of our international relations. Honourable members are sharply divided as to the attitude we should adopt towards this ancient nation, now recovering like a giant from 40 years of internal disorders. We should, I suggest, distinguish between short-term and long-term policies. It is unreasonable of Mr. Chou-En-Lai to expect diplomatic recognition at this stage by the TJnited States of America, Australia, or any other democratic country. British experience in this respect since 1950 has been anything but encouraging. Moreover, the Chinese have been declared aggressors in Korea by the TJnited Nations; and their intervention in Indo-China is a matter of common knowledge. Before China can expect diplomatic recognition and admission to the TJnited Nations, it must first prove itself a good neighbour, and willing to conduct itself according to the principles of the Charter. Hitherto, China's conduct has been the reverse. The Peking Government is symbolized by those not pirates who, from time immemorial, have infested the Canton Eiver. Nevertheless, it is folly for us to ignore China. After all, Australia is a Pacific power, and we find ourselves, broadly speaking, in the same ocean as the Chinese. It seems probable that the Communist regime has come to stay. We cannot depose Mao-Tse-Tung and his armies by our own actions. Neither can we disregard indefinitely the rulers of one-fifth of the world's population. Without prejudice to the creation and maintenance of the South-East Asia Treaty Organization, it will be in Australia's interests to aim ultimately at achieving a modus vivendi with Peking. However repugnant this may sound to many people, we are confronted by these facts. First, China is rapidly gaining strength. Its troops in Korea have proved themselves to be of high quality. Eeports from Australian servicemen returning from Korea are disconcerting and disturbing. China's intervention in Indo-China has been largely responsible for France's defeat. Secondly, there will be no stability in East Asia, so long as China is bent upon disturbing it. Thirdly, it will be wholly contrary to the Chinese character to become simply the echo of Moscow. China will evolve its own form of communism, suited to its needs. Marxism diluted, Orientalized, may well assume different expressions from those of Eussia. One of the cardinal precepts of Anglo-American policy must therefore be the breaking of the Moscow-Peking axis. Fourthly, over the centuries, there has been contact between the British and Chinese people. Not only our ancestors, but those of us who have had personal experience of the Chinese, both in peace and war, have found them compatible as a race-. They possess characteristics in some respects sympathetic to our own. We shall be wise to use this friendly predisposition as a springboard for political understanding. In the long run, we may have more to gain by reaching an accord with China, than by continually urging the rearmament and militaiy resurrection of Japan. China may soon emerge as the dominant power of the Orient. It is just possible that it will prove more trustworthy than the arrogant, scheming and ambitious Japanese. In making these observations, [ do not wish to be misunderstood. This is not a plea for recognizing red China this year or next year. Nor am I arguing for compromising over Eormosa, or bargaining from onr present condition of embryonic South-East Asian union. But I do ask honourable members to distinguish between short-term and long term objectives, and not to close their minds to establishing relations with Peking whenever that government has displayed convincinely its good intentions. During the coming years, whilst preparing for the worse, let us seize any f r u it f u l opportunity of making contact with the Chinese, as the Britisli Foreign Secretary did so successfully last month at - Geneva. In our right hand we must carry a sword, but in our left hand we should also carry friendship.

Speaker: Mr LUCHETTI
Title: EOYAL COMMISSION ON
text: Macquarie) [5.18] This is not a time for flowery speech, rhetoric and the calculated phrase to arouse public feeling, but it is time for members of this Parliament to consider dispassionately the problems facing Australia. The words uttered by the Prime Minister (Mr Menzies) and the Minister for External Affairs (Mr Casey), couched in language more diplomatic than practical, have little relation to the problems confronting Australia at the present time. The people of Australia look to the Government for something better than double talk and language which gives no positive lead to the nation. At present, we need from the Government leadership of a kind that will give confidence to the people of this, our land. The problems facing the people of Australia are real and grave. No one will deny that. our position is fraught with grave danger. Our great poet, Henry Lawson, wrote thatBy our place in the midst of the farthest seas We are fated to stand alone. That is true. We lead Western culture in this area, and we have much to surrender, if the forces from the north, aided and activated by Communist aggressors, find their way to Australia. Because of that, there is need for action on the part of the Government, instead of long speeches which do no more than recount the past, and give historical surveys of happenings years ago. We want positive action at the time to deal with those problems so vital to our very existence. The ministerial statements on international affairs which have been presented to the House during the last fortnight, should have been made almost immediately after the last general election. The Parliament, if it is to play a useful part in the affairs of this nation, should have been summoned earlier for the purpose of dealing with the matters that we are elected to consider. The people of Australia look to this Parliament and the Government to try to do something to maintain peace, and, failing peace, to make this country secure against possible aggression. The measure of success that has attended the efforts of the Minister for External Affairs can be gauged from ?-ecent happenings in Indo China. Peace has been secured in that country at a price which cannot be applauded by fair-minded people throughout the world. I deplore the fact that 13,000,000 people, who have fought valiantly for their freedom, have been surrendered, and that essential industries have been handed over to forces which, perhaps, will use those resources eventually in further drives southwards. Because I feel that, the ministerial statements made in this Parliament have a very hollow ring. I believe that we should try to do something for the achievement of peace. What has this Government attempted in "that respect ? It has not made a report to the Parliament on the matter. So far as I am aware, the Minister for External Affairs has not on any occasion made to the Parliament a statement that would help to achieve peace in this part of the world. If a course of conduct could be adopted where we lay the foundations of peace, and better understanding in the Pacific, I am sure that the majority of honourable members would be only too happy to grasp the opportunities to weld bonds of friendship between the people of Australia and our Asian neighbours. The reason is plain. We must live in the world with them. It is our destiny to live with them. But no proposals in that respect have been submitted to the Parliament. On the contrary, all the evils which bring the onrush of communism closer to Australia, and the forces that has been set loose by imperialism and exploitation bave been allowed to go unchecked. I must be critical of the attitude of the Government of France to the IndoOhina situation. One can hardly feel otherwise on this subject. A country wliicli has been unable to maintain a government from week to week, or month to month, could not be expected to look after its colonies, and preserve law and order outside its domestic realm. The Maginot Line complex has been the complex of France for a number of years. I believe that the spirit of France died with the fall of the Maginot Line, and has not been re-born since that happening, which was so unfortunate for the free peoples of the world. France, instead of building a strong and virile nation which could play its part in world affairs on terms of equality with the great powers, was content to rest behind the Maginot Line in the hope that all would be well, and the countiy would be secure. That complex has struck a grave blow at the spirit of France, and in my opinion, a moral decline is the result. The people of France today can see the unhappy fruits of theiiconduct over the years. I deeply regret that a part of Indo China, particularly Viet Nam, has been handed over by a sovereign power to Ho-Cbi-Minh's people without very much consideration for the inhabitants of that unhappy area who have fought so valiantly for freedom, ancl peace. How could that tragedy occur? The ruler of that unhappy land has been in southern France for some time where he has"been enjoying the many luxuries, delights and diversion's to be found there. One thing that we have always been able to say is that, in any turmoil, trouble and strife, the Kingis still in London. Bombs could fall on London, but the King was - still in his capital. But the ruler of Indo-China was in southern Prance while his country was being divided between the rival forces. Now, we in this - Parliament arc 1 being asked to authorize the despatch of our troops to areas where the inhabitants are not taking the defensive measures which could be expected of them. I have here the report of a speech delivered in the TJnited States Congress, which states that, np to May of this year, the French authorities had not effected the complete mobilization of the people of Viet Nam. If that were so, it was a shocking state of affairs. I ask honourable members to consider the position. The world was not given an opportunity, through the TJnited Nations, to come to grips with this problem. France desired to reserve to itself the right to deal with its problem as a domestic mattei , but was not prepared to 1 mobilize the people of Viet Nam to defend that territory. I can only con elude that the cause was lost from the beginning. I am not saying a word against the heroism of the people concerned. Those who fought against Communists deserve the highest praise. But I do condemn those in authority who surrendered the people who have fought for principles and their way of lifn. They were surrendered by a government which sought to keep faith with a timetable at a conference at Geneva. Indo-China has suffered, and I believe that it is necessary for us to pay attention now to conditions in other parts of South East Asia. What is the condition of Malaya, Siam and Burma? Are they prepared to play their part in the defence of their areas? If they are not, is it reasonable to suppose that we, in Australia, with a population of 9.00.0,000, should send troops to any of tliose areas? The position should be made clear. I am not satisfied that all is well. I am absolutely certain that all is wrong in Indonesia; the position there is most unsatisfactory. This Government may not 'be able to solve the problem in Indonesia, but at least it can do something about the problems of Australia. I return to the need for the development of better relations. between Australia and neighbouring countries. I have obtained details of our representation in various countries in close proximity to Australia, and I find that, in Indonesia, we have a Minister and six other persons, including typists, at Djakarta. That is completely unsatisfactory. I think we should be represented much more adequately. Our problems are linked with those of the Asian area, and it would be much better for us to reduce our consular representation in other parts of the world, if necessary, in order centrate upon representation in Asia. We should take a much closer official interest 'in Indonesia particularly. Travellers returning from overseas have told me that the Indonesians entertain an absolute hatred for white people, including Australians. This is a most disturbing state of affairs when Australians have only the utmost goodwill for the people of Indonesia. We have no territorial aims or ambitions, and we have no desire to take from other peoples anything that they possess, to exploit them, to develop any form of imperialism, or to dominate them as subject races. We are out to help the people of Indonesia and to cultivate friendship with them on the widest and most generous terms. If we are to do so, however, our representation in Indonesia should be on the highest level and as extensive as our resources will permit. We must try to reach the minds of the Asian people. I know that it is very difficult to bring the Occident and the Orient together, but we have much in common with Indonesians. For example, we have common economic interests. Let us. therefore, find ont what goods we can sell to them in addition to the goods that they now buy from us. and what goods » we can take from them in return. Surely we can establish complementary trade relations to the mutual advantage of both countries. We have been told that the TJnited Kingdom representative in South East Asia, Mr Malcolm Macdonald is doing au outstandingly good job. Australia should try to work along similar lines and, in addition to the career diplomats whom we send overseas, we Mr Luchetti. should send men who will really try to meet the ordinary people of Asia on all levels instead of merely making social contacts at the Grand Hotel or at fashionable luncheon and dinner parties. We should be represented by men able to talk to Asians of all classes. Australian representation at Dilli, in Portuguese Timor, also is most unsatisfactory. We have only a consul there. In Manila we are represented by a minister and two other persons. At Bangkok we have a similar staff. At Bangoon there are a minister and three others. At Saigon we have the same representation. At Singapore, there are a commissioner and four other persons. At Noumea we have only a consul to con- and one other person. In my opinion, that is totally inadequate. Unfortunately we have no control over the foreign policies of other nations. We could do nothing, for example, to influence the attitude of M. Mendes-France, when he made a deal over Viet Nam to a time-table at Geneva. However, we can do much to promote the future welfare of Australia. My grievance against this Government is? that it is not doing many things that ought to be done now in order to preserve Australia's interests. If we stand in grave peril, as the Prime Minister and the Minister for External Affairs have said, the Government should be up and doing to provide for the development of the nation. The honourable member for Kennedy (Mr Eiordan) spoke of the need for vast developmental works in Queensland. He referred to the urgent need for the construction of a bridge over the Burdekin Eiver, but his remarks on that subject were lightly brushed aside. In my estimation, good transportation is essential to the defence? of Australia. It would be fatal to fall again into the mistake of providing too little too late. John Curtin truly ex-' pressed the views of the Australian people when he said of the anti-Labour administration early in World War II . that its members were defeatist in outlook and in. their preparations for defence. That criticism can be applied with a great deal of justice and truth to the present _ Government. The shocking weakness of our defences in the Northern Territorv. the failure to try to populate and develop northern Australia, the neglect of the Clapp report in favour of the standardization of railway gauges and the refusal to rationalize our transport systems so that, in the event of war, we shall be able to move men freely and speedily throughout this vast island continent, stand shamefully to the discredit of the Government. It has ignored Australia's urgent needs and has done nothing to promote security from attack. All our vital national works undertakings, such as the bauxite development project, the Snowy Mountains hydro-electric scheme, and the Bell Bay aluminium undertaking were initiated by Labour governments. Under this Government, we see such wanton aets as I have witnessed in the electorate that I represent, where the source of an important oil supply at Glen Davis was closed down and where an Army camp at Bathurst was declared to be surplus and made available for sale. That camp was vital, during World War II , but this Government declares it to be unnecessary now. It is disgraceful that an establishment that cost hundreds of thousands of pounds should be disposed of at this grave and critical period of our history. The Government has shown no realism in such matters. AVe must, if we are to survive as people, establish a self-sufficient economy ancl a degree of self-sufficiency in military persuaded strength. We must be able to lay our nation hands on the aircraft, the motor vehicles and the other equipment that .we need. It would be fatal to wait for war to begin ditional, before we acted. The failure of the Gocountry. vernment to provide for our national security cannot be due entirely to its ignorance of our needs. Deficiencies are brought to the attention of Ministers from time to time. I have often reminded the Government of weaknesses from Up which we suffer, and I recall vividly occasion when a Minister told me, in reply to a question that I had asked, that it was unlikely that we should opposed in the future by a great maritime power. Apparently that member of Government chooses our opponents ancl the sort of navy that they shall use! Anybody who understands the internaAustralia. tional situation today knows that the honourable gentleman was dangerously wrong. He shoidd read Jane's Fighting Ships, which shows that Australia's potential enemies are capable of assembling a vast submarine fleet that could seriously inconvenience us in the event of hostilities.

Speaker: Mr DEAN
Title: EOYAL COMMISSION ON
text: Eobertson) [5.38] - This is not the first occasion on which I have had to speak in succession to the honourable member for Macquarie (Mr. Luchetti), but I listened with great interest to the speech that he made this afternoon. The honourable gentleman complained that the Government had failed to give leadership to the Australian people and that there was an urgent need for action at this period of our history. I noticed that he failed to say whether or not lie supported the important line of leadership and action that the Prime Minister (Mr Menzies) announced, without any qualification, in his statement on international affairs. Indeed, no member of the Opposition has explained where he stands on this issue. Honourable members will recall that the Prime Minister said that the Government had decided that, in any great defensive organization of the kind envisaged in South-East Asia, Australia must accept a free military commitments. He also saidHonorable members will not need to be by me that for us, as a democratic vitally at risk in these seas, to expect our great friends to accept commitments wliile ouv own attitude remained tentative and conwould be utterly inconsistent with the intelligence, character and record of our As the honourable member for Macquarie doubtless realizes, this policy represents a great change from the previously accepted plan for the defence of Australia. to the present, we have only talked of one the probable nature of our commitments in the event of war. Never before has Australia entered without qualification be into commitments in advance of war. The honourable member for Macquarie the asked what the Government had done to promote peace, and he referred particularly to the countries to the north of I can reply briefly but effectively to the honourable gentleman's plaintive inquiry by referring him to the Colombo plan under which great economic assistance has been given to countries to the north of Australia in order to enable them the better to withstand the menace of communism. The honourable member also complained of the possibility that the services of Australian men and equipment might be used to defend the people of Indo-China. I shall refer briefly to that complaint now, but I shall enlarge upon the subject later in my speech. The simple fact is that it is absolutely necessary for us to contain our potential enemies within their present geographical limits. The honourable member referred to Australia's lengthy coastline. It is true that, with our small population, our small volume of equipment, and our relative economic weaknesses, it would be impossible for us to defend that coastline effectively. Therefore, we must assist our friends and allies in every possible way to prevent the further expansion of our potential enemies. Of course, notwithstanding anything that the honourable member may have said, Australia has been making closer contacts with our neighbours in South-East Asia for a considerable time. World attention has been focused on this area only recently, and this is due largely to the recent events in Indo-China. The Minister for External Affairs made an important statement on communism in South-East Asia on the 16th May, when he said that Indo-China was a country. . . wiiere communism is most militant unil dangerous now that Comniunist ambitions in Europe have received a set-back. This region is of great importance to Australia's --eeurity. Since then, of course, the cease-fire arrangement has come into effect in Indo China and the industries of Viet Nam in the north have fallen under the control nf the Communists, so that once again valuable territory and millions of people have been taken behind the iron curtain. Some people describe the events of the last seven or eight years as episodes in a cold war. That description is completely false and unrealistic. The Communists conquered North Korea and Yiet Nam with hot bullets, and, despite all the conferences and peace negotiations, they have not lost effective control of one square foot of the territory that they have thus gained. We know only too well that more Mr Dean. plans are being prepared for further Communist expansion. Communist imperialism, with its policy of enforced colonization by tyranny, is again on the march. That tenn "colonization" has been mentioned several times in this debate as a feature of glib Communist, propaganda. Such propaganda is used to disguise many deeds that have been inspired by Moscow. The Leader of the Opposition (Dr Evatt) said that there was a governing class in England that would not recognize the just claims of the peoples of India, Pakistan, Ceylon and Burma, referring to previous colonization of these countries by Great Britain. But what are the facts? When Mr. Attlee presented the bill to grant India independence to the House of Commons on the 4th July, 1947, he used the following words:It has been the settled policy of all parties in this country ior many years that the Indians in the course of time should manage their own affairs. Members of all parties in the British Parliament warmly welcomed and supported the measure. The bill under which Ceylon was granted independence was similarly supported by all parties in the British Parliament. I shall refer later to the differences between British colonization methods and those of other countries, and to the fact that the people of the Asian countries have far more confidence in the British Commonwealth of Nations than they have in other countries. I said earlier that Communist imperialism, this new type of colonization with tyranny, is once again on the march, and that all of us are menaced. It menaces Australia and all the members of the British Commonwealth, the United States of America, Thailand, Malaya, Burma, Ceylon, India, Pakistan, Indonesia and the Philippines. All of us must recognize that the attempts of the Communists to identify themselves with nationalistic movements in South East Asia and elsewhere are based on a fraud. The facts are that Btissian imperialism, which is the driving force of international communism, has enslaved the nations that are now the satellites of Russia in Europe, and is now trying to grab the Asian countries as well in the same way. All of us who belong to the - free world must do our bestto prevent the continuance of thia policy of grab. Of course, the people who are immediately' threatened are those who inhabit the countries north of Australia. As has already been pointed out in tkis debate, tliere are approximately 170,000,000 people living within a radius of 2,000 miles of Darwin. The largest part of the world supply of tin, rice, rubber ancl other materials, is grown in that area. Suggestions have been made, both inside and outside this House, about the possibility of Australia sending its surplus wheat to some of the Asian countries. They are not well considered suggestions because, in addition to the reasons advanced by the Minister for Commerce and Agriculture (Mr MCEwen) in answer to a question today, many Asian people do not eat wbeat. We have had instances of wheat having been sent to countries that were facing a famine but, despite their hunger, the people of these countries would not eat it. Any such scheme that is envisaged should be investigated fully to ensure that the people of countries to which we might send wheat are willing to accept it. To those who think only of Australian defence-and speeches from the Opposition side during this debate have shown that there are such peopleI say that the area north of Australia provides the most obvious route for any potential aggressor to approach our mainland. We must widen onr thinking. The free and stronger nations of the world must help the weaker, threatened nations. Australia is one of the free, strong nations. We must arm ourselves against Communist tyranny and make such pacts as will halt the onward march of communism. The Prime Minister pointed out in his statement that there are free nations in Asia which are justly proud of their independence. If , in the beginning, some of these nations join any proposed pact only through the fear of communism, we must do all we can to inspire their confidence in us, so that association with them can be lasting and of great economic value as well as of mutual military assistance. It is not surprising that certain Asian countries regard some Western moves with suspicion. I think it is not necesciation. sary for us to go very far back in OUT history to understand why.. Nevertheless, it is true to say that the Asians have more confidence in the British people than in any other people. History also, shows us thereason for that. I advanced' some reasons for it. at the beginning of my remarks. An additional reason is that the British have developed a more enlightened colonialism than any other country has developed. In answer to some of the statements made by honourable members opposite I shall give the House an example of that. Britain gave India a. peace within its boundaries that was previously unknown, and later gave it self-government. Because of our geographical position alone, if for no other reason, Australia must be one of the leaders in forming any mutual pact. The first thing we must do i.s to treat the formation of a mutual security treaty as a matter of extreme urgency. We must make it plain that such a pact will not threaten the sovereignty of any nation. We must also ensure that any economic benefits that flow from the treaty will be to the advantage of all its members.. In addition, we must work hard in order to ensure that we shall have the physical means to protect the other signatories to the treaty so that no member country will be abandoned to Communist tyranny imposed from without. The most important and urgent task will be to continue talking democracy to the Asian people as well as economic assistance. This is something in which I think the British Commonwealth could show greater energy than it has shown in the past. We know that elections are to be held in two years' time in Viet Nam, Laos, and Cambodia. It is no easy task to convert a country that has a high percentage of illiteracy into a functioning democracy, when so few of its people have a practical knowledge of the art and science of government. I think we can be sure that our the Communists are already energetically organizing for the forthcoming elections. The British Commonwealth may be a loosely-knit association, but it gives a proof to the world that people of various races, backgrounds and religions can live together in peace and in profitable assoThe British nations which have clone so mucb. to prove the value of democracy to the world should, I suggest, send teams into the Asian countries to help to bring democracy to them. Teams for democracy! They could assist, as the honourable member for Macquarie (Mr Luchetti) stated to-night, not only in the economic development of the countries but also in spreading the truth of democracy. They would be a counter to the highly organized cells of the Communists which have no doubt already started work in these areas preparatory to the coming elections. In this regard f. should like to make one comment to the Minister for External Affairs (Mr. Casey), who is now at the table, t hope that the Government will maintain the representation in Laos and Cambodia which I understand it now has, and that it will increase that representation if possible. consider also that it would be valuable to send a fact-finding mission from Australia to such countries as Thailand, Burma, and then on tc Ceylon, India and Pakistan before the teams that I have mentioned are sent in. Members of this Parliament should be included in that mission, which should also include men with wide commercial and industrial experience, both inside and outside of Australia, as well as people with experience of primary production, so that the inquiries could cover a wide field. We could thus receive the best possible advice about the nature of the work that the teams that I propose would have to do, especially in the near north of Australia, in the countries that, are most threatened because they are immediately in the path of advancing Communist imperialism. The mission, of course, would also - be a goodwill mission, and would assist in removing the misunderstandings and barriers that we know exist between ourselves and the Asian people. The work of the teams, in conjunction with economic aid to the Colombo Plan countries, would provide an example of co-operation between the east and the west, snch as exists in the British Commonwealth, and we might thereby be able to achieve the confidence and trust of the countries concerned. Finally, I wish to touch on the for Australia to provide the equipment speech. Jfr. Dean. and troops necessary to assist any of our friends who join the South-East Asia Treaty Organization. In the last warAustralia became a base for our allies. We provided them with food, clothing and equipment. We must go forward in that way, instilling confidence in the people we offer to aid and working to our mutual advantage.  adjourned. INDO-OHINA.

Speaker: Mr CASEY

Title: EOYAL COMMISSION ON
text: Sitting suspended from G to S p.m. INTERNATIONAL AFFAIRS. Debate resumed.  am conscious of the fact that the subject before the House for debate, the matter of international affairs and foreign relations, is possibly the most complex and difficult that one could address himself to. I am also conscious that to speak on this subject involves a great sense of responsibility, and that the individual should express his views irrespective of the consequences and irrespective of the popularity of the comments that he might make. I believe that the peoples of the world,' irrespective of their religions political philosophies and modes of life, seek the four great freedoms which were so well phrased by the great Churchill and the great Roosevelt when they announced that they and the allied troops were fighting for freedom of worship, freedom from fear, necessity freedom from want and freedom of At the moment honourable members and the Australian people are, by virtue of a chain of circumstances directly associated with this debate, more concerned with a search for freedom from fear. During the last few months I have realized, by reason of discussions at Geneva and in the United Nations, and by articles published in the press of the world, that the people of this and other countries have expressed a real fear that they are in danger. When the phrase " freedom from fear " was coined, it was designed to convey to the people that it should apply not only to Christians, but also to the people of all parts of the world. That is why I say that I hope that even the people who are directly, and by inference, considered to be our enemies, will eventually be placed in such a position as will enable us all to say that we shall, by every means at our disposal, endeavour to bring about freedom from fear, freedom from want, freedom of speech and freedom of worship throughout the world. Anything that I might say in criticism of the policies of our great friends in the United States of America, and of our great friends and former allies of France, must not be considered to be other than a criticism of a very friendly nature. We look to those friends and allies today for further friendship and assistance, and they are very great people indeed and have the same Christian principles and outlook on life as we ourselves endeavour to preach and practice. During the long tedious course of this debate, all the Government has put before us is an attitude. Indeed, no policy of any sort whatsoever has been placed before this Parliament. The Government has merely struck an attitude. It has brought to this House the outcome of the negotiations at Geneva, which have fortunately temporarily brought peace to the war-stricken part of Asia that is known as Indo-China. The Government has brought to the House the possibility of the formulation of a treaty, to be known as the South East Asia Treaty Organization. Most of the speakers on behalf of the Government, including Ministers, have addressed the House, intentionally or unintentionally, to the effect that already the Government is committed to a South East Asia Treaty Organization. They have not emphasized that at the moment no such treaty, nor, indeed, any concrete proposals, have been brought forward for discussion; nor have they indicated to the House the nature of the conditions that would be contained in a treaty that they consider should be agreed to by this country, the Americas and any other friendly people who may be prepared to join us. The Government has allowed us to believe that we are already committed to a treaty. Let me inform the people that no such treaty exists. It is quite true that the Government has given this Parliament an assurance that when a treaty, which they have almost committed themselves to in advance, has actually been formulated, it will be submitted to the Parliament for its approval. I repeat that the Government has lead the people to believe that a document actually exists, that proposals are in evidence and that now all that requires to be done at a later stage is to put on the table of this Parliament a treaty which contains certain written obligations on the part of Australia, the. Americas, parts of Indo-China possibly, and other friendly countries, and say " We have consulted our Parliament". What they really mean to say is that they have confronted us with a fait accompli. The Government will say " We have the numbers so through the Parliament it goes ". Then the people will find that they are possibly committed to an obligation to send troops, arms, naval vessels, aircraft that and war materials to the mainland of Asia under the terms of the so-called South-East Asia Treaty Organization. Mr GULT.ETT - No one understands the position better than the honourable member.  member need not interject. I am not without some knowledge of what happens with regard to international agreements and treaties. I recollect the negotiations that took place in regard to the Internationa] Wheat Agreement. Australian ministers and their deputies meet the ministers and deputies of other countries. They concoct an arrangement and then go back and say to their Parliaments' " We have agreed as a government to be a party to an international agreement" and then, at the last moment, they throw the agreement on to the tables of their parliaments for discussion. They are involved in what is in effect a fait accompli. Of course in those circumstances no parliament has any other alternative, because of the superior numbers of Government members, but to give effect to the Government's arrangement. text: Order ! The konoriible member should not answer interjections.  Vice-President of the Executive Council (Sir Eric Harrison) has no right to interject while I am speaking. The tenor of this debate is that something is already in existence. The Government has not said directly that a treaty organization exists, but the people believe that there is some arrangement already in operation. The Government has a duty to make it quite clear to those people that no treaty yet exists. It also has an obligation to indicate now, quite clearly and unequivocally, the nature of the agreement that it will be willing to sign. I know the Minister for External Affairs (Mr Casey) will say that the subject matter that the proposed treaty is to contain will be hammered out in consultation with onr friends in America and the TJnited Kingdom. But we want to know now what this Government believes should go into that treaty, and what obligations the Government expects this country to undertake. I make that statement with particular emphasis, because I believe that despite our small population, aud because of our geographical position and the influence of onr opinions on world opinion in the past, it is not beyond the realms of possibility that if we were to express concise propositions in this Parliament, and if they were to be wisely phrased by the Government and wisely conveyed to our friends and allies, our representations would have great influence. T have emphasized my friendship the American people, and therefore I can say that everybody knows that at present speeches are being made and propaganda is being issued in the Americas ahout the policy that the world, and in particular those countries involved in South East Asia, should, follow. Tliere is a belief in some parts of America that in order to contain communism, the American .peoples should have a foothold on the soil of Asia. There are people who believe that nationals in Asia should be deprived of their right to determine whether they will accept communism or otherwise. Indeed, I believe that that opinion is very prevalent in the Americas. It is my firm opinion that we have a right to our political philosophies and a right to adhere to our great democratic system, which is the best system of government the world has known. But I remind honourable members that in World War I . we fought for the right of all people to seK-determination within the confines of their own territories. In those circumstances, if the nationals of a particular country decide that, because of the failure of other forms of government in their country, they desire to institute a philosophy or form of government that is alien and hateful to us, surely it is tlieir right to do so. I believe that we should indicate to all the peoples of the world, including those in America, that as far as we are concerned-and I pay tribute to some honourable members on each side of the House for their speeches in this regard-w e are not in favour of one Australian foot being put on the Asian continent in order to prevent people who are anxious to get rid of all European domination from exercising that which they believe is their inherent right-the right to self-determination. We should say quite frankly that we do not believe that Australian battleships and destroyers, and Australian aircraft, should not enter Asian waters and Asian skies to prevent that self determination. In the past, unlike the Chifley Government, this Government has shown evidence that it has no foreign policy. During this debate honourable members, including the Prime Minister (Mr Menzies) himself, have admitted that the trouble that has occurred in for South-East Asia and Indo-China is largely due to an upsurge of nationalism, aad that we should have sympathy with those people in their attempt to assert their nationalism. The Government has also said that communism has used these nationalist movements as a vehicle to get control of, or play a part in, the governments of those countries. But this Government does not tell us that while these people were engaged in an upsurge of nationalism against the great French people in Indo-China, the Australian Government was sending <terms and munitions of war to the French in order to help them to destroy those people who were indulging in an upsurge of nationalism.

Does the right honourable gentleman, as an intelligent person, believe that, although those people are rice-eaters, ,tliey would not be glad to supplement their diet with some wheaten product, enjoy it, and become more responsible citizens of their country ?

Speaker: Mr BOSTOCK
Title: EOYAL COMMISSION ON
text: Indi) [8.20] - The honourable member for Lalor (Mr. Pollard) has treated the House to a good deal of rhetorical rubbish. Very few of his statements require a reply. He charged the Government with having no foreign policy. On the face of it, that statement is complete nonsense. The foreign policy of the Government has been explained very clearly on more than one occasion by the Minister for External Affairs (Mr Casey). To put it in a nutshell, the foreign policy of this country is to make friends with its neighbours and to ensure its own security. That statement of policy covers all of the policy actions of the Government. The suggestion of the honourable member for Lalor that the Government, by its policy, is frustrating those people in South-East Asia who wish to determine their own destiny or who, to use his own words, are seeking self-determination, also is nonsense. The Government will encourage by every possible means, as its actions have already shown, the self-government and self-determination of any people. It has no intention of interfering with the domestic affairs of any nation, provided the domestic affairs of that nation are not shaped towards an end which threatens the security of Australia. To say that the difficulties and troubles in Indo-China are purely national is to close one's eyes to the provable facts. The difficulties and troubles in Indo-China are patently Communist inspired. As such, they are a threat to our own national security. The sending of arms to Indo-China was a proper action which was not intended to assist the French people to suppress any national movement but to assist in the defence of Australia against Communist aggression. It is inevitable that, in a debate of this kind, there will be much repetition in sense, if not in words. The international situation is such that Australia's very existence is threatened. That threat is obvious to any thinking Australian, but I do not believe that the Australian people as a whole appreciate the significance of the agreement that was recently reached between the French and the Comniunist forces in Viet Nam. Even at the risk of repetition, it is appropriate that I should trace very briefly a chain of events that may flow from the cessation of hostilities in Indo-China. The Prime Minister (Mr Menzies) has already warned us that we would be foolish indeed if we thought that the cease-fire in .Indo-China meant an end of the intentions of the Communist aggressors. The agreement provides that there shall be a general election in Viet Nam in 1956. If the result of that election were unfavorable to the democracies and if Viet Nam became a Communist State, which is within the realms of probability, and if Laos and Cambodia were overrun, the only remaining buffer State between Communist imperialism and Burma and Malaya would be Siam. Burma is a tempting bait to the Communists in their quest for world domination, because it is an important rice-growing country and, as such, must have an important effect unon the political and economic policies of the countries of South-East Asia. The occupation of Burma, by Communist forces would be a direct threat to India. On the other hand, the conquest of Malaya, which is also a tempting bait to the Communists, wonld enable the Chinese to obtain substantial supplies of tin and rubber. The Chinese are largely dependent upon Russian resources. The fact that they dislike that dependence is revealed in their plans for industrial expansion. They are in great need of raw materials and, to some degree, Malaya could satisfy that need. Unless the Communist objective is greatly modified, we can expect the Communists to include Malaya on their list. If Malaya is overrun, it is difficult to see how Indonesia can survive. Indonesia, which is rich, in rubber and oil, also is a tempting bait to the Communists. The Indonesians are likely to become half-willing victims. Communist propaganda in support of an upsurge of nationalism, particularly propaganda that would inevitably raise the cry, " Western New Guinea for the Indonesians", probably would raise much enthusiasm in the Indonesian people. If western New Guinea fell into Communist hands, how long do honourable members think that the Territory of Papua and New Guinea would remain undei our control in spite of possible intervention by the TJnited Nations If that chain of' events took place, the penultimate situation would be that the Chinese Communists would sit at Port Moresby and look down the Queensland coast. That is a line of aggression that may be pursued by the Communists, and against which we must guard while we have time. Our best military safeguards lie in some form of collective pact. For that reason, the Government has proposed and has subscribed to the establisliment of a South-East Asia Treaty Organization, on the lines of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. But military preparation is not all that is required. In this regard I agree wholeheartedly with honourable members from both sides of the chamber who have addressed themselves to the subject. At this stage, it is vital that in addition to making military preparations we shall develop friendly relations with those nations of South-East Asia that arc not already engulfed by the Communist forces, and that we shall also ensure that they realise the advantages of self-government, compared with slavery under communism, and exercise correctly the right that the TJnited Nations, the TJnited States of America, Australia and all other democratic countries will endeavour to guarantee for them-the right to self-determination of their own affairs. I emphasize that that aetion must be taken now. Australia's first line of defence Malaya, where, if necessary, we must stand ancl fight. It will be much easier and much more economical to assure defence of Malaya if we preserve the integrity of Siam, the only completely independent state remaining between Malaya and Communist-dominated terriequal tory. In the best interests of peace we should immediately make it abundantly clear to the Chinese Communists that any threat to Siam will be regarded as direct and immediate threat to Malaya, and, in consequence, as a direct threat to Australia. Holding these views as strongly as I do, I . was particularly interested to hear from the Prime Minister last Thursday evening that Australia had at last abandoned phantom military planning. By that I ? mean that, contrary to past policy, when we make military plans in the future we must, at the time those plans are made, consider commitments to back them with force, and not leave those commitments to be determined at some indefinite future date. I trust that those commitments will be substantial. I say so, because, as is well appreciated by all honourable members, no nation, not even the great United States of America, can defend itself alone. We all,' great and small powers alike, are dependent for our security to some degree upon the support of our friends and allies, and Australia, in the situation peculiar to it, is probably more dependent upon its friends than is any other of the Western democracies. We must convince our friends that we are sincere and honest in our professed intention to defend ourselves. At present we have not succeeded in doing that. It js apparent from our defence expenditure that our efforts are badly lagging behind those of other nations. Defence expenditure in the United Kingdom is approximately .45 per cent, of the total' budget expenditure. In the United States of America it is about 70 per cent, of the total budget expenditure. In Australia, however, defence expenditure amounts to less than 20 per cent, of the total budget expenditure. This being so, we cannot prevent some niggling criticism occurring among our best friends. We look to them to defend us, but we are not ready to put forward anything like as great an effort as is in they are making on our behalf. Mr J. B-. Speaker: Mr BOSTOCK
Title: EOYAL COMMISSION ON
text: I appreciate that, and I realise that we probably cannot afford to expend on defence an amount to 70 per cent, of the budget expenditure, but I point out that there is a great difference between 20 per cent, and 70 per cent. I am sure that we can do much a better than 20 per cent. I trust that when the question of commitments comes under consideration, as it must and should do, we shall be more generous than we have been in the past. I trust that if the occasion arises^- I do not know whether it will - the Australian Government will propose that Australia, as an independent nation within the British Commonwealth, should volunteer to undertake the responsibility for the defence of Malaya. I do not refer to full-scale defence in war-time, which obviously would be well beyond our capacity, nor do I think for one moment that Australia could assume unaided the responsibility for maintaining the peacetime garrison that is necessary in Malaya in present circumstances. The TJnited Kingdom at present does not undertake alone the provision of the peace-time garrison needed in Malaya. It calls on its friends for assistance, and Australia has answered that call by contributing to the defence of Malaya. Should we not be justified in making a similar call on our friends for help if we accepted responsibility for the defence of Malaya, which concerns our very existence more than it does that of any other Western ' democracy ?

Speaker: Mr BOSTOOK
Title: EOYAL COMMISSION ON
text: Shoul d we not be justified in asking Great Britain, the TJnited States of America and the nations that it is proposed shall subscribe to Seato, to help us should we assume responsibility for the defence of Malaya? It may be that Australia's contribution will be so small that such an arrangement would be impossible, but at least we should make the offer and emphasize our good intentions and our willingness to defend ourselves to the utmost of our ability. If we were to expend on defence as large a proportion of the budget expenditure as is devoted to defence purposes by the TJnited States of America, or even the TJnited Kingdom, the proposal would not be so fantastic as it seems at the moment. In this debate suggestions that Australia should not send forces abroad have come from honourable members on both sides of the House. The honourable member for Dalley (Mr Greenup) a moment ago asked whether I would leave Australia undefended. My reply is that the consequences will be nothing short of national suicide if we devote our military resources to the strengthening of defence forces in Australia and complacently sit behind them until we are attacked within our own territory. Our first line of defence at present lies in Malaya, and not in Australia. It might be inferred from what I have said that I place more emphasis on the military aspect of this problem than on the economic aspect, but I do not intend to convey that impression. Every one knows from experience that it is impossible to come to terms or to bargain with the Soviet and Communist powers except from a position of strength. Consequently, economic measures against communism are likely to be nullified unless the democracies can back them with strength in the form of military preparedness. It is necessary, therefore, that the two instruments of military and economic measures for our defence be used in conjunction. We should do much better to fight hopefully in Malaya than forlornly in Queensland. 1 Mr Whitlam (Werriwa) [8.42] The fact that for more than three years the House has not been allowed to participate in a debate on foreign affairs is a damning indictment of the Government. Title: EOYAL COMMISSION ON
text: Thing s have improved in the meantime. The Minister's statement on that occasion related to the first meeting of the ANZUS council, which had taken place a month before. The statement was not debated until a year later, when the second meeting of the ANZUS council was in progress. The Minister for External Affairs has made otlier statements on Korea, meetings of the TJnited Nations General Assembly, and the like. None of those statements was debated, and all were allowed to lapse with the prorogation of the Parliament. During the last week the House has had the good fortune to hear statements, first, by the Prime Minister (Mr Menzies) on foreign affairs, and, secondly, by the Minister for External Affairs on South East Asia. We have had the even better fortune to hear the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Evatt) debate both those statements. This is virtually the first time in three years that the elected representatives of the people have had the opportunity to express their views on international affairs for the Government's consideration, and it is the first occasion in more than three years that the Government has deigned to listen to the views of the people's representatives on this matter. - In the exciting and rapid movement of events during the last few months the Minister for External Affairs has twice circumnavigated the globe in the steps of his model, Mr Eden, and his master, Mr Dulles. Though the Minister saw fit to make statements to the newspapers in the TJnited States of America and in other parts of the world, he did not say anything to the - Australian press. The only Minister who has seen fit to make any statement on international affairs has been, of all people, the Postmaster General (Mr Anthony), who three weeks ago addressed the annual conference of the Queensland branch of the Australian Country party. In haranguing that rally of rustics the Postmaster-General declared that we Australians cannot live in peaceful co-existence with the Communists in this cold war. That pronouncement, fortunately, was in direct contradiction of statements that had already been made by President Eisenhower, of the TJnited States of America, and Sir Winston Churchill, the British Prime Minister. The declaration of the Postmaster-General has been emphatically repudiated in this House by the Prime Minister and the Leader of the Opposition. As a consequence of that rash utterance, the Postmaster-General, whose health in recent months was deemed to be rapidly qualifying him for a diplomatic post, has rendered himself nersona non grata to every head of State except President Syngman Rhee of the Republic of Korea, and General Chiang Kai-shek, the leader of the Chinese Nationalist Government. B -[10 ] Eor the first time since Japan invaded Manchuria, there is peace on the continent of Asia, and for the first time since World War I . began 40 years ago, there is neace throughout the world. During the last three days honourable members have exercised their minds in recrimination and soul-searching at this unwonted state of affairs, and many honourable members have criticized the French, who tliey allege have let the free world down, and also the action of the Chinese Communist Government in intervening in Indo-China. I want to make my position in this matter perfectly plain. I do not blame the French one jot. Their eallantry in the seven and a half years during which they carried on the struggle in Indo-China cannot be denied. They may have been ill-advised. I certainly believe that they were, but it does not become any of us to criticize the forlorn hope of Dien Bien Phu. We can recall that Indian summer of French colonial glory when General de Lattre de Tassigny restored the French position temporarily and was, posthumously, awarded the grandest military title in the world-Marsha l of France. At the same time, it is useless for us to blame the Chinese for intervening. China was not the only country to intervene in Indo-China. The Chinese were the first to recognize Ho-Chi-Minh as the head of State in Viet Nam. In fact, when the nationalists took over the occupation of northern Viet Nam, after the Japanese were defeated, Chiang Kai-shek recognized him in September, 1945, and armed him with Japanese arms. The French recognized Ho-Chi-Minh in March, 1946, and later that year negotiated with him at Fontainebleau. The French broke with him in December, 1946. It was in December, 1949, that Chinese troops reached the Viet Nam border. For the first three years of the war, Ho-Chi-Minh did not receive, because he could not receive, any help from Mao-Tse-Tung. Until the elections are held in Viet Nam in 1956 there will continue to be turmoil in that area. The tragedy is that those elections will be the first ever to be held in Indo-China. Australia faces the dilemma that if war comes and Australia is attacked, the only country that can render it any assistance is the United States of America. Yet the policies very often advocated by that country are in complete disagreement with tliose advocated and acted upon hy all our neighbours. I am not suggesting that we should take notice, to the point of action, of everything that leaders of Congress and of the American armed forces say. President Eisenhower has followed a middle course, and in view of public opinion in the United States of America one must admire him for following a sane and consistent course. It is unfortunate that the separation of legislative and executive functions in the United States of America relieves members of the American Congress of taking responsibility for their utterances. It also unfortunate that Admirals Radford, Carney and Stump are not members of a silent service. The solution t'hat is often suggested for the dilemma in which we find ourselves is that we should join a South-East Asia treaty organization on the analogy of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization which experienced considerable success in the northern hemisphere in stemming the marcli of communism in that area. But although the United States of America, the United Kingdom probably, and ourselves prepared to join such an organization, none of our neighbours are prepared to do so. India has certainly said that it will not join, and Indonesia and Burma have taken a similar stand, whilst Ceylon has said that it will follow India. Pakistan has said that it will attend a conference on the proposed organization, but that country has not committed itself to join the organization. The temper of those countries is reflected in a statement that was made last month by the Indonesian Foreign Minister when he saidSuch a regional defence community in sliould be initiated by Asian powers selves. For Asian countries the problem was how best to develop n common defence based on unity of interest. If the South-East Asia Treaty Organization is to be valid at all, it allowed must represent South-East Asia, but it cannot be said that the organization will represent that area if the only Asian Ur. Whitlam. countries that join it are the Philippines and Thailand. That fact has been publicly acknowledged in the Philippines in a statement that was made two weeks ago by Senator Claro Recto, the Nationalist Government's foreign policy spokesman. He saidAn alliance excluding India, Indonesia, Pakistan, Burma and Ceylon will not be representative of South-East Asia. Thailand is of particular significance, because it may well be the country in which the next civil war, as some people would call it, or subversion, as other people would call it, may break out. The reason is that Thailand has a great Chinese minority which presents all the makings of a civil war, whilst coups is d'etat have characterized politics in the country in recent years. Fearful of the number and skill of the Chinese in Thailand, the country has been opposed to the Governments of Chiang Kai-shek and of Mao-Tse-Tung, and successive Thai governments have sought the assistance of outside powers to counterhas balance the Chinese influence. Just as Japan provided that bulwark for Thailand during the war, the United States of America serves that purpose in the interests of Thailand today. One great fault of the South-East are Asian Treaty Organization compared with the North Atlantic Treaty Organization is that the North Atlantic Treaty Organization secured the support and co-operation of the government of every country on both sides of the North Atlantic seaboard, with the exception of Spain and Eire, and it also obtained the co-operation of the maritime powers of the Mediterranean. So, all the relevant countries were represented in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization; and for that reason it has been successful. Conversely, if all the relevant countries are not represented in the South-East Asia Treaty Organization the organizaAsia tion will not be a success, and we shall themonly delude ourselves in joining any organization of that kind in such circumstances. Certain phases of our policy have been to continue for four and a half years to the provocation of the people of China and of all our neighbours. I refer to the question of the recognition of the Communist Government in China and to its admission to the TJnited Nations. "Whether we like it or not, all of the Colombo plan nations have recognized the Government that is installed in Peking. At Colombo, on the 1st May last, the Prime Ministers of those five countries, four of which are members of the TJnited Nations whilst the fifth, Ceylon, has failed to gain membership because of the exercise of the veto by Soviet Russia, said in a joint communiqueThc representation of the People's Eepublic of China, the Prime Ministers felt, would promote stability in Asia, ease world tension and assist in bringing about a more realistic approach to problems concerning the world, particularly in the Far East. It cannot be said that any of those countries are Communist-inclined, because in the same communique those five Prime Ministers statedThe Prime Ministersaffirmed their faith in democracy and .democratic institutions and, being resolved to preserve in their respective countries the freedoms inherent in a democratic system, declared their unshakable determination to resist interference in the affairs of their countries by external communist, anti-communist or other agencies.
